eda_steps.step_description: Interactive box plot visualization showing the distribution of all four numerical features (sepal and petal measurements) grouped by iris species.
step_insights: Petal measurements show much clearer species separation than sepal measurements, with minimal overlap between species
Iris-setosa is clearly separable from the other two species across all features, particularly petal measurements
PetalLengthCm and PetalWidthCm demonstrate the strongest discriminative power for classification

dataset_description: The Iris dataset contains 120 training samples with 4 numerical features measuring sepal and petal dimensions in centimeters. This is a classic multi-class classification dataset from R.A. Fisher's 1936 taxonomic study with perfectly balanced classes (40 samples per species).

columns.name: Id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each sample, not used in modeling
columns.additional_information: Sequential ID column that provides no predictive value for species classification

columns.name: SepalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the sepal in centimeters, ranging from 4.3 to 7.9 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with moderate discriminative power for species classification

columns.name: SepalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the sepal in centimeters, ranging from 2.0 to 4.4 cm
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature with some overlap between species but still contributes to classification

columns.name: PetalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the petal in centimeters, ranging from 1.0 to 6.9 cm
columns.additional_information: Most discriminative feature showing excellent species separation with minimal overlap

columns.name: PetalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the petal in centimeters, ranging from 0.1 to 2.5 cm
columns.additional_information: Highly discriminative feature that clearly separates Iris-setosa from other species

columns.name: Species
columns.description: Target variable with three iris species: Iris-setosa, Iris-versicolor, and Iris-virginica
columns.additional_information: Perfectly balanced target with 40 samples per class in the training set

eda_summary: The Iris dataset presents an ideal multi-class classification scenario with excellent feature separability. Petal measurements (length and width) demonstrate superior discriminative power compared to sepal measurements, with Iris-setosa being linearly separable from the other two species. The dataset is perfectly balanced, contains no missing values, and all features are on similar scales (centimeters), which simplifies preprocessing requirements. The clear feature separability suggests that relatively simple classification algorithms should achieve high performance.
